response.message: You paid for a chat room, when you could have just used IRC? That VC money is going to your heads!

I remember a whole lot more blah blah blahing between bits there.

The whole exercise proved to me that Jeff is right.

These chat rooms get dominated by a couple loudmouths who think that their personal "friend hunts" are more important than the topic at hand. There was little to no restraint exercised in the room. What a mess.

@Frank that's why we posted an edited summary transcript!

This was more of a public performance. In general inviting 100 random people into a public chat room is a bad idea and won't lead to anything useful.

The way this is *typically* done, is you'd have 3 or 4 moderators seeing a raw public chat and only pushing appropriate questions over to the "real" chat room.

But that solution is specific to "public Q&A with a popular public figure" format.

Thanks for posting this, Jeff. I think the chat was excellent, and provided a great opportunity for the community to get just a bit more insight into the growth taking place at SO.

As noted, it was a bit messy at times in the room, but I think it was a diamond in the rough, and your edited transcript above exercised the diamond and showed the great potential in these types of settings.

Hopefully this will become a somewhat regular thing for you guys in the future - with more planning and tact, of course.

Shame I missed the chat, but thanks for posting up the summary.

I know it says that doing 'software' is off the table, but I was wondering whether any thought will be given to some kind of view-only engine to go with the data dumps so that once a site 'dies' from inactivity its latest state can easily be hosted for viewing by anyone that wants to maintain a copy of its last state? Would be perfect if the view-only engine is visually mostly indistinguishable from the previously live version.
Yeah, it was kind of a mess, but I really appreciated the idea.  If only we could have used our SO logins.  Then perhaps Joel wouldn't have to continually ban the fake Jeff A. :-P

@jerryjvl 
A couple of the FOSS clones can import SO data dumps

@jerryjvl  There are already open source clones of the SO engine that allow you to us the data dump and fire your site right back up.  I don't see that its worth it for the SO team to spend any time going the route of make a subset of their code for viewing only.

That's fair enough too then... I've never looked too closely at the data-dump posts, but I don't think it has a link to any of this software. It might be worth having something with the dumps that points to the software you can use to just import it?

Anyway, withdrawing my original comment ;)
First mention of an enterprise version, glad to see the "community" and "making the internet a better place" hasn't completely taken over :P
